Standard_Text: Combine clauses in a wide variety of ways (e.g., rearranging complete simple sentences to form compound sentences) to make connections between and join ideas (e.g., The boy was hungry. The boy ate a sandwich. The boy was hungry so he ate a sandwich) in shared language activities guided by the teacher and independently.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Combine clauses in an increasing variety of ways to make connections between and join ideas, for example, to express cause/effect (e.g., She jumped because the dog barked) in shared language activities guided by the teacher and with increasing independence.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Combine clauses in a few basic ways to make connections between and join ideas (e.g., creating compound sentences using and, but, so) in shared language activities guided by the teacher and sometimes independently.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Connecting ideas
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Connecting and Condensing Ideas
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Expand simple and compound sentences with prepositional phrases to provide details (e.g., time, manner, place, cause) in shared language activities guided by the teacher and independently.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Expand sentences with prepositional phrases to provide details (e.g., time, manner, place, cause) about a familiar or new activity or process in shared language activities guided by the teacher and with increasing independence.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Expand sentences with frequently used prepositional phrases (such as in the house, on the boat) to provide details (e.g., time, manner, place, cause) about a familiar activity or process in shared language activities guided by the teacher and sometimes independently.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Modifying to add details
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Expand noun phrases in a wide variety of ways (e.g., adding a variety of adjectives to noun phrases) in order to enrich the meaning of phrases/sentences and add details about ideas, people, things, and so on, in shared language activities guided by the teacher and independently.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Expand noun phrases in a growing number of ways (e.g., adding a newly learned adjective to a noun) in order to enrich the meaning of sentences and add details about ideas, people, things, and so on, in shared language activities guided by the teacher and with increasing independence.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Expand noun phrases in simple ways (e.g., adding a familiar adjective to describe a noun) in order to enrich the meaning of sentences and add details about ideas, people, things, and so on, in shared language activities guided by the teacher and sometimes independently.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Using nouns and noun phrases
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Use a wide variety of verb tenses appropriate for the text type and discipline to convey time (e.g., simple present for a science description, simple future to predict) in shared language activities guided by the teacher and independently.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Use a wide variety of verbs and verb types (e.g., doing, saying, being/having, thinking/feeling) in shared language activities guided by the teacher and independently.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Use a growing number of verb tenses appropriate for the text type and discipline to convey time (e.g., simple past tense for retelling, simple present for a science description) in shared language activities guided by the teacher and independently.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Use a growing number of verbs and verb types (e.g., doing, saying, being/having, thinking/feeling) in shared language activities guided by the teacher and independently.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Use simple verb tenses appropriate for the text type and discipline to convey time (e.g., simple past for recounting an experience) in shared language activities guided by the teacher and with increasing independence.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Use frequently used verbs (e.g., go, eat, run) and verb types (e.g., doing, saying, being/having, thinking/feeling) in shared language activities guided by the teacher and with increasing independence.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Using verbs and verb phrases
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Expanding and Enriching Ideas
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Apply understanding of how ideas, events, or reasons are linked throughout a text using a variety of connecting words or phrases (e.g., first/second/third, once, at the end) to comprehending texts and composing texts in shared language activities guided by the teacher, with peers, and independently.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Apply understanding of how ideas, events, or reasons are linked throughout a text using a growing number of connecting words or phrases (e.g., next, after a long time) to comprehending texts and composing texts in shared language activities guided by the teacher, collaboratively with peers, and with increasing independence.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Apply basic understanding of how ideas, events, or reasons are linked throughout a text using more everyday connecting words or phrases (e.g., one time, then) to comprehending texts and composing texts in shared language activities guided by the teacher, with peers, and sometimes independently.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Understanding cohesion
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Apply understanding of how different text types are organized predictably (e.g., a narrative text versus an informative text versus an opinion text) to comprehending texts and composing texts in shared language activities guided by the teacher, with peers, and independently.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Apply understanding of how different text types are organized to express ideas (e.g., how a story is organized sequentially with predictable stages versus how an informative text is organized by topic and details) to comprehending texts and composing texts in shared language activities guided by the teacher, collaboratively with peers, and with increasing independence.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Apply understanding of how text types are organized (e.g., how a story is organized by a sequence of events) to comprehending and composing texts in shared language activities guided by the teacher, with peers, and sometimes independently.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Understanding text structure
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Structuring Cohesive Texts
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Learning About How English Works
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Use a wide variety of general academic and domain-specific words, synonyms, antonyms, and non-literal language to create an effect (e.g., using the word suddenly to signal a change) or to create shades of meaning (e.g., The cat's fur was as white as snow) while speaking and composing.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Retell texts and recount experiences using increasingly detailed complete sentences and key words.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Use a growing number of general academic and domain-specific words in order to add detail or to create shades of meaning (e.g., using the word scurry versus run) while speaking and composing.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Retell texts and recount experiences using complete sentences and key words.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Use a select number of general academic and domain-specific words to add detail (e.g., adding the word spicy to describe a favorite food, using the word larva when explaining insect metamorphosis) while speaking and composing.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Retell texts and recount experiences using a select set of key words.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Selecting and applying varied and precise vocabulary and language structures to effectively convey ideas
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Offer opinions and provide good reasons with detailed textual evidence or relevant background knowledge (e.g., specific examples from text or knowledge of content).
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Offer opinions and provide good reasons and some textual evidence or relevant background knowledge (e.g., paraphrased examples from text or knowledge of content).
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Offer opinions and provide good reasons (e.g., My favorite book is X because X.) referring to the text or to relevant background knowledge.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Supporting own opinions and evaluating others' opinions in speaking and writing
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Draw, dictate, and write to compose longer literary texts (e.g., story) and informational texts (e.g., an information report on dogs), collaboratively with an adult (e.g., joint construction of texts), with peers, and independently using appropriate text organization.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Draw, dictate, and write to compose short literary texts (e.g., story) and informational texts (e.g., a description of dogs), collaboratively with an adult (e.g., joint construction of texts), with peers, and with increasing independence.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Draw, dictate, and write to compose very short literary texts (e.g., story) and informational texts (e.g., a description of a dog), using familiar vocabulary collaboratively in shared language activities with an adult (e.g., joint construction of texts), with peers, and sometimes independently.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Composing/writing literary and informational texts to present, describe, and explain ideas and information, using appropriate technology
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Plan and deliver longer oral presentations on a variety of topics in a variety of content areas (e.g., retelling a story, describing a science experiment).
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Plan and deliver brief oral presentations on a variety of topics (e.g., show and tell, author's chair, recounting an experience, describing an animal).
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Plan and deliver very brief oral presentations (e.g., show and tell, describing a picture).
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Expressing information and ideas in formal oral presentations on academic topics
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Productive (creation of oral presentations and written texts)
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Distinguish how multiple different words with similar meaning (e.g., walk, march, strut, prance) produce shades of meaning and a different effect.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Distinguish how two different words with similar meaning (e.g., describing an action as walk versus march) produce shades of meaning and a different effect.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Distinguish how two different frequently used words (e.g., describing an action with the verb walk versus run) produce a different effect.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Analyzing how writers and speakers use vocabulary and other language resources for specific purposes (to explain, persuade, entertain, etc.) depending on modality, text type, purpose, audience, topic, and content area
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Describe the language an author uses to present or support an idea (e.g., the vocabulary used to describe people and places), with prompting and light support.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Describe the language an author uses to present an idea (e.g., the adjectives used to describe a character), with prompting and moderate support.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Describe the language an author uses to present an idea (e.g., the words and phrases used when a character is introduced), with prompting and substantial support.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Evaluating how well writers and speakers use language to support ideas and opinions with details or reasons depending on modality, text type, purpose, audience, topic, and content area
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Describe ideas, phenomena (e.g., insect metamorphosis), and text elements (e.g., major events, characters, setting) using key details based on understanding of a variety of grade-level texts and viewing of multimedia, with light support.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Describe ideas, phenomena (e.g., how butterflies eat), and text elements (e.g., setting, characters) in greater detail based on understanding of a variety of grade-level texts and viewing of multimedia, with moderate support.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Describe ideas, phenomena (e.g., parts of a plant), and text elements (e.g., characters) based on understanding of a select set of grade-level texts and viewing of multimedia, with substantial support.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Reading closely literary and informational texts and viewing multimedia to determine how meaning is conveyed explicitly and implicitly through language
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Demonstrate active listening to read-alouds and oral presentations by asking and answering detailed questions, with minimal prompting and light support.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Demonstrate active listening to read-alouds and oral presentations by asking and answering questions with oral sentence frames and occasional prompting and support.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Demonstrate active listening to read-alouds and oral presentations by asking and answering yes-no and wh- questions with oral sentence frames and substantial prompting and support.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Listening actively to spoken English in a range of social and academic contexts
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Interpretive (comprehension and analysis of written and spoken texts)
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Offer opinions in conversations using an expanded set of learned phrases (e.g., I think/don't think X. I agree with X, but…), as well as open responses, in order to gain and/or hold the floor or add information to an idea.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Offer opinions in conversations using an expanded set of learned phrases (e.g., I think/don't think X. I agree with X), as well as open responses, in order to gain and/or hold the floor.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Offer opinions and ideas in conversations using a small set of learned phrases (e.g., I think X), as well as open responses.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Offering and supporting opinions and negotiating with others in communicative exchanges
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Collaborate with the teacher and peers on joint composing projects of informational and literary texts that include a greater amount of writing (e.g., a very short story), using technology, where appropriate, for publishing, graphics, and the like.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Collaborate with the teacher and peers on joint composing projects of informational and literary texts that include some writing (e.g., short sentences), using technology, where appropriate, for publishing, graphics, and the like.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Collaborate with the teacher and peers on joint composing projects of short informational and literary texts that include minimal writing (labeling with a few words), using technology, where appropriate, for publishing, graphics, and the like.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Interacting with others in written English in various communicative forms (print, communicative technology, and multimedia)
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Contribute to class, group, and partner discussions by listening attentively, following turn-taking rules, and asking and answering questions.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Contribute to class, group, and partner discussions by listening attentively, following turn-taking rules, and asking and answering questions.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Contribute to conversations and express ideas by asking and answering yes-no and wh- questions and responding using gestures, words, and simple phrases.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Exchanging information and ideas with others through oral collaborative conversations on a range of social and academic topics
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Collaborative (engagement in dialogue with others)
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Interacting in Meaningful Ways
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: End: Write their first name on their own in Eng­lish nearly correctly, using letters of the English alphabet to accurately represent pronunciation in their home language.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Middle: Attempt to copy their own name in English
or in the writing system of their home language.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Beginning: Write marks to repre­sent their own name
in a way that may resemble how it is written in the home language.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
End: Continue to develop writing by using
letters or letter-like marks to represent their ideas in English.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Middle: Begin to use marks or symbols to represent
spoken language in the home language or in English.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Beginning: Begin to demonstrate an awareness that
written language can be in the home lan­guage or in English.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
End: Develop an increasing understanding that
what is said in English can be written down and read by others.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Middle: Begin to understand that what is said in
the home language or in English can be written down and read by others.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Beginning: Begin to understand that writing can
be used to communicate.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Children use writing to communicate their ideas.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Writing
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
End: Begin to orally manipulate sounds
(onsets, rimes, and phonemes) in words in English, with support.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Middle: Begin to use words in English with
phonemes (individual units of meaningful sound in a word or syllable) that are different from the home language.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Beginning: Attend to and manip­ulate different sounds
or tones in words in the home language (as reported by parents, teachers, assistants, or others, with the assistance of an interpreter if necessary.)
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
End: Recognize and produce words that have a similar onset
(initial sound) in English.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Middle: Begin to recognize words that have a
similar onset (initial sound) in the home language or in Eng­ lish, with support.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Beginning: Listen attentively and begin to participate in simple songs, poems,
and finger plays in the home language or in English.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
End: Repeat, recite, produce, or initiate
simple songs, poems, and finger plays that emphasize rhyme
in English.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Middle: Begin to repeat or recite simple songs,
poems, and finger plays that emphasize rhyme in the home language or in English.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Beginning: Listen attentively and begin to participate in simple songs, poems,
and finger plays that emphasize rhyme in the home language or in English.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Children demonstrate phonological awareness.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
End: Identify ten or more letters of the
alphabet in English.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Middle: Identify some letters of the alphabet in
English.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Beginning: Begin to recognize the first letter in their own
name or the character for their own name in the home language
or English.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
End: Begin to demonstrate understanding that
the letters of the English alphabet are symbols used
to make words.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Middle: Begin to talk about the letters of the English
alphabet while play­ ing and interacting with them; may code- switch (use the home language and English).
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Beginning: Interact with mate­ rial representing the
letters of the English alphabet.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Children demonstrate progress in their knowledge of the alphabet in English.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
End: Recognize in the environment (class­
room, community, or home) an increasing number of familiar symbols, words, and print labels
in English.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Middle: Recognize in the environment (class­
room, community, or home) some familiar symbols, words, and print labels in the home language or
in English.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Beginning: Begin to recognize that symbols in the environment (class­
room, community,
or home) carry a consistent meaning in the home language or in English.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Children demonstrate awareness that print carries meaning.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
End: Demonstrate an understanding that
print in English is organized from left to right, top to bottom, and that pages are turned from right to left when a book is read.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Middle: Continue to develop an understanding of how to read a book, sometimes applying
knowledge of print conventions from the home language.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Beginning: Begin to understand that books are read in a consistent man­ ner (e.g., in English,
pages are turned from right to left and the print is read from top to bottom, left to right; this may vary in other languages).
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Children demonstrate an understanding of print conventions.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
End: Retell in English the majority of a story
read or told in English.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Middle: Retell a story using the home language
and some English when read or told a story in English.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Beginning: Retell a story in the home language when read or told a story in
the home language (as reported by par­ents, teachers, assis­tants, or others, with the assistance of an interpreter if neces­sary).
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
End: Begin to engage in extended
conversations in English about stories.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Middle: Describe their own experiences related
to the topic of the story, using tele­ graphic and/or formulaic speech in English.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Beginning: Begin to identify and relate to a story from
their own life experi­ences in the home language (as reported by parents, teachers, assistants, or others, with the assistance
of an interpreter if necessary).
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Children show an increasing understanding of book reading.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
End: Choose to “read” familiar books
written in English with increasing independence and talk about the books in English.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Middle: Choose to “read” familiar books written in the home language
or in English with in­ creasing independence and, in the home language or in English, talk about the books.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Beginning: “Read” familiar books written in the home
language or in English when encouraged
by others and, in the home language, talk about the books.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
End: Participate in read­ ing activities, using a variety of genres that are written in English
(e.g., poetry, fairy tales, concept books, and informational books).
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Middle: Begin to participate in reading activities, using books written
in English when the language is predictable.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Beginning: Attend to an adult reading a short
storybook written in the home language or a storybook written
in English if the story has been read in the home language.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Children demonstrate an appreciation and enjoyment of reading and literature.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Reading
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
End: Produce simple narratives in English
that are real or fictional.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Middle: Begin to use English to talk about personal
experiences; may complete a narrative in the home language while using some English (i.e., code- switching).
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Beginning: Create a narrative in the home language (as
reported by parents, teachers, assistants, or others, with the assistance of an inter­ preter if necessary).
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Children use language to create oral narratives about their personal experiences.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
End: Appropriately use words and tone of
voice associated with social conven­tions in English.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Middle: Demonstrate a beginning under­
standing of English social conventions.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Beginning: Use social conven­tions of the home
language (as reported by teachers, parents, assistants, or others, with the assistance
of an interpreter if necessary).
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Children begin to understand and use social conventions in English.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
End: Begin to use “what,” “why,” “how,”
“when,” and “where” questions in more complete forms in English, sometimes with errors.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Middle: Begin to use “what” and “why” questions
in English, sometimes with errors.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Beginning: Ask a variety of types of questions (e.g.,
“what,” “why,” “how,” “when,” and “where”) in the home language (as reported by parents, teachers, assistants, or others, with the assistance of an interpreter if necessary.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
End: Expand the use of different forms of
grammar in English (e.g., plurals; simple past tense; use of subject, verb and object), sometimes with errors.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Middle: Begin to use some English grammatical
markers (e.g., -ing
or plural –s) and, at times, apply the rules of grammar of the home language to English.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Beginning: Use age-appropri­ate grammar in the
home language (e.g., plurals; simple past tense; use of subject, verb, object), some­ times with errors
(as reported by parents, teachers, assistants, or others, with the assistance of an interpreter if necessary).
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: End: Increase utterance length in English by adding appropriate possessive pronouns (e.g., his, her); con­ junctions (e.g., and, or); or other elements (e.g., adjectives, adverbs).
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Middle: Use two- and three- word utterances
in English to communicate.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Beginning: Use a range of utter­ ance lengths in the home language that is age-appropriate (as reported by parents, teachers, assistants, or others, with the assistance of an inter­ preter if necessary).
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
End: Sustain a conversa­ tion in English about
a variety of topics.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Middle: Begin to converse with others, using
English vocabulary but may code-switch (i.e., use the home language and English).
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Beginning: Converse in the home language (as reported
by parents, teachers, assistants, or others, with the assistance of an interpreter if necessary).
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
End: Use new English vocabulary to share
knowledge of concepts.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Middle: Begin to use English vocabulary, mainly
consisting of concrete nouns and with some verbs and pronouns (telegraphic speech).
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Beginning: Use vocabulary in the home language that
is age-appropriate (as reported by parents, teachers, assistants, or others and with the assistance of an inter­ preter if necessary).
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
End: Show increasing reliance on verbal communication in
English to be under­ stood by others.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Middle: Combine nonverbal and some verbal
communication to
be understood by others (may code­ switch—that is, use the home language and English—and use telegraphic and/or formulaic speech).
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Beginning: Use nonverbal com­ munication, such as
gestures or behaviors, to seek attention, request objects, or initiate a response from others.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Children use nonverbal and verbal strategies to communicate with others.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Speaking
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
End: Demonstrate an un­ derstanding of words
in English related to more advanced concepts.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Middle: Begin to demonstrate an understanding of
words in English related to basic concepts.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Beginning: Demonstrate an understanding of
words related to basic and advanced con­ cepts in the home language that are appropriate for the age (as reported by parents, teachers, assistants, or others, with the assistance
of an interpreter if necessary).
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
End: Follow directions that involve a one- or
two-step sequence, relying less on contextual cues.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Middle: Respond appropri­ately to requests in­volving one step when personally directed
by others, which may occur with or without contextual cues.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Beginning: Begin to follow simple directions in English,
especially when there are contextual cues.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Later: Begin to demonstrate an understanding of a larger set of words
in English (for objects and actions, personal pronouns, and pos­ sessives) in both real and pretend activity.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Middle: Demonstrate under­ standing of words in
English for objects and actions as well as phrases encountered frequently in both real and pretend activity.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text:
Beginning: Attend to English oral language in both real
and pretend activity, relying on intonation, facial expressions, or the gestures of the speaker.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Children listen with understanding
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Listening
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)
